_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



The Dakota Yeast LLC (formerly Minn-Dak Yeast Company) is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from any hazardous substances used in its yeast manufacturing process, specifically aqueous ammonia.  It is the policy of Dakota Yeast LLC to comply with all Federal, State and Local laws.





Facility Description and Regulated Substance Handled



The Dakota Yeast LLC operates a yeast manufacturing facility located in Wahpeton, Richland County, North Dakota.  Aqueous ammonia, at 30% concentration, is a key component in the manufacture of yeast.  The liquid ammonia is fed into the sealed process and is completely used during the process.  The maximum amount of aqueous ammonia stored on-site is 120,000 pounds.





General Accident Release Prevention Program



Through completion of this RMP, the Dakota Yeast LLC has complied with the EPA requirements under 40 CFR Part 68.  Process safety information and operations/maintenance procedures are documented on site.  Periodic functions such as process hazard analysis, training, change management and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis.  There have been improvements in reporting and recording emergency and preventative maintenance needs for the system.  Audits of the overall RMP will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA regulations.





Five-Year Accident History



No ammonia accidents causing death, environmental or property damage, evacuations, or in-place sheltering have occurred in the last five years at the yeast manufacturing facility.





The Emergency Response Program



In the event of an emergency, it is a policy of the Dakota Yeast LLC to notify the local (Dwight Township Fire Department and/or City of Wahpeton) Fire Department and evacuate all employees from the facility.  A new addition to this program is a new factory distributed control system.  This system gives us the ability to remotely shut o

ff pumps and close automatic valves for the aqueous ammonia system.





Planned changes to Improve Safety



Future changes to the risk management program for aqueous ammonia is to coordinate tours with the local fire and emergency response departments.  During these tours, plant operations management will be available to answer any questions the emergency responders may have.
